This face corresponds to the base of the part. **Step 5: Scale the 2D sketch** Apply a uniform scale of 0.75 to the 2D sketch. **Step 6: Transform 2D sketch to 3D** Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the given Euler angles and translation vector. The resulting 3D sketch will have the same curve topology as the 2D sketch. **Step 7: Extrude the 3D sketch** Extrude the 3D sketch along the normal direction by 0.5597 units. This will generate a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a slightly tapered top. Part 1 is now complete with the following dimensions: - Length: 0.75 - Width: 0.5597 - Height: 0.75</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Creating the Base of the Prism Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Begin by creating a new coordinate system at the origin with no rotation or translation. Step 1: Drawing the 2D Sketch 1. Create a new sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system. 2. Draw line 1 starting from (0, 0) and ending at (0.75, 0). 3. Draw line 2 starting from (0.75, 0) and ending at (0.75, 0.75). 4. Draw line 3 starting from (0.75, 0.75) and ending at (0, 0.75). 5. Draw line 4 starting from (0, 0.75) and ending at (0, 0). Step 2: Scaling the 2D Sketch Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Step 3: Transforming the Scaled 2D Sketch into a 3D Sketch Keep the normal vector intact but translate the scaled 2D sketch by (0, 0, 0). Step 4: Extruding the 2D Sketch to Generate the 3D Model Extrude the 2D sketch along the normal vector, resulting in a height of 0.75 units. Part 2: Creating the Cut on the Prism Create a cut on the prism. Begin by creating a new coordinate system at point (0, 0, 0.75) with no rotation. Step 1: Drawing the 2D Sketch 1. Create a new sketch on face 1 of the coordinate system. 2. Draw line 1 starting from (0, 0) and ending at (0.3089, 0). 3. Draw line 2 starting from (0.3089, 0) and ending at (0.3089, 0.2819). 4. Draw line 3 starting from (0.3089, 0.2819) and ending at (0, 0.2819). 5. Draw line 4 starting from (0, 0.2819) and ending at (0, 0). Step 2: Scaling the 2D Sketch Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.3089. Step 3: Transforming the Scaled 2D Sketch into a 3D Sketch Keep the normal vector intact but translate the scaled 2D sketch by (0, 0, 0). Step 4: Extruding the 2D Sketch to Generate the 3D Model Extrude the 2D sketch opposing the normal vector (in the direction of z-negative), resulting in a height of 0.75 units. The final 3D prism has dimensions of 0.75 units for the base length, width, and height, and is cut by a deeper prism with dimensions equivalent to 0.3089 units multiplied by 0.75 units over each dimension.</description>
